mdxSource.renderedOutput:
Î»\lambdaÎ»-calculus is a mathematical system for describing functions. Any computable function can be evaluated in the context of Î»\lambdaÎ»-calculus, and evaluating programs in the language consist of a single transformation rule: variable substitution.

That in itself was a good enough motivation to get me started on this. This would not be a tutorial, but I'd try making sense of what I did in the past weeks and why you should be doing it too, maybe?

Imagine deducing a medium where you have no arithmetic, boolean, or other operations. You can only use functions. Also, this function calculates nothing. It is just a kind of expression, with a head and a body. It just stands there. The only thing we can do with it is to resolve it.

Quick detour: Lambdas are curried. Î»abc.a\lambda abc.aÎ»abc.a is just shorthand for Î»a\lambda aÎ»a.Î»b\lambda bÎ»b.Î»c\lambda cÎ»c.a (even with the brackets.) Î»\lambdaÎ»-calculus has excellent overlap with combinatory logic. What are combinators? Î»\lambdaÎ»'s with no free variables as the output.

Abstracting the definition of the given function even further. Some of them could be (combinators):

  • Identity: Iâ‰”Î»x.xI \coloneqq \lambda x.xI:=Î»x.x
  • Self-application: Mâ‰”Î»x.xxM \coloneqq \lambda x.x xM:=Î»x.xx
  • Cardinal: Câ‰”Î»xy.yxC \coloneqq \lambda xy.yxC:=Î»xy.yx

( MI=IM I = IMI=I, how? Self apply Identity on Identity.)

And more and more, but essentially, only a few combinators are needed as the basis to span the space of all functions.

Even with generating booleans and numbers, the idea remains consistent, giving a completely different meaning to doing arithmetic on numbers (apply some other function on two functionsðŸ¤¯). You can find a talk on it here.

Diving further, it was a mess initially? But then, understanding the inductive proofs, recursive structures, reductions, type-systems, and the works of Church and Haskell got me an absolute fanboy.

In the end, I'd suggest giving Î»\lambdaÎ»-calculus a read on some random weekend.

Some resources just in case:

  • The introductory blog you need.
  • Notes from the talk.
  • Bit complicated.
  • All the reductions oof.
  • Another fascinating read.
